datasource: Heine, Bernd (1974/75) 'Notes on the Yaaku language (Kenya)', Afrika und Übersee, 58(1), 27–61; 58(2), 119–138. Heine, Bernd & Brenzinger, Matthias (1988) 'Notes on the Mukogodo dialect of Maasai', Afrikanistische Arbeitspapiere, 14, 97–131. [BH75;H&B88]

Vowels.inventory: i e ε a ɔ o u

geodemoTXT: Varieties and subdialects of Yaaku are spoken in Kenya, ZZIsiolo and Laikipia counties: Mukogodo forest west of Doldol, foothills north of Mount Kenya; Turkana and Samburu counties: Lake Turkana south tipZZ.

termclusters.label: yak-Verb-gwe-Perfect
termclusters.note: BH75pp.56f :: Preceded by locative preposition ou. Sentences are glossed “be in Nairobi”

termclusters.label: yak-Verb-gwe-Present
termclusters.note: BH75pp.56f :: Preceded by locative preposition ou. Sentences are glossed “be in Nairobi”

termclusters.label: yak-Verb-kus-PastDefiniteAffirmative
termclusters.note: BH75pp.51-54 :: “If the verb is preceded by constituents other than the subject,then it takes a prefix me- or ke-. Such pre-verbal constituents may be conjunctions,intrerrogative words,or object nouns. … The presence of me- usually implies a progressive action

termclusters.label: yak-Verb-loo-FutureIndefiniteAffirmative
termclusters.note: BH75pp.57f :: –lo’o “differs from other verbs in that it does not distinguish personal suffices. The prlural suffx is for both indefinite and definite aspect –ni. Past and Perfect markers are ee- and ene- rather than aa- and na-,respectively

termclusters.label: yak-morphVerb-SubjSuffDefiniteNegative
termclusters.note: BH75pp.45;48 :: On formSets:“It seems hardly possible to generalize on the token of these suffixes as almost every verb as a set of its own.” These are not distinguished in the negative.
